awd_titl_txt: CAREER: High-Frequency Power Electronics for Wireless Power Transfer Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless power transfer (WPT) has the potential to address critical energy issues and improve human quality of life by enabling autonomous charging in applications ranging from electric vehicles (EVs) and robotics to portable electronics and biomedical implants. For example, efficient, small, cost-effective, and safe WPT can drastically reduce the need for expensive and bulky on-board batteries, extend range, and accelerate EV penetration. With road transportation accounting for 22% of the nation's total energy consumption, and EVs having roughly twice the well-to-wheel efficiency of gasoline vehicles, even a 10% EV penetration (versus 0.1% currently) can reduce total U.S. energy consumption by over 1%. Likewise, effective WPT can enable artificial heart pumps without abdominal-wall-penetrating electric cords, avoiding discomfort and potential infections for the 5.1 million people in the U.S. suffering from heart failure. Furthermore, WPT could eliminate the need for cardiac pacemaker battery replacement surgeries for nearly 40,000 people each year. However, for WPT systems to be widely adopted, considerable improvements are needed in their performance, cost, and safety. This integrated research and education career development proposal aims to make fundamental advancements in high frequency (1-100 MHz) power electronics technologies, and leverage exciting WPT applications to ignite the imagination of future engineers. The program's broader educational goals include the training of graduate research students and undergraduates participating through the University of Colorado's (CU) Discovery Learning Apprenticeship Program. Incorporating the research findings into the CU Boulder curriculum and disseminating the findings more broadly through a free online course will enhance the education of students at CU Boulder, community colleges, and elsewhere. The special outreach program for K-12 students, involving them in the development of educational videos, will expose them to the role of power electronics and WPT in improving energy efficiency and quality of life and attract them to pursue STEM careers. 


To achieve the goal of WPT systems with efficiencies, sizes, and safety comparable to their wired counterparts, the research objectives of this CAREER proposal are to: (i) generalize the new step-superposition (S2) analysis technique introduced by the PI, and use it to better model and optimize high-order resonant converters with multiple inverters and/or rectifiers; (ii) innovate and employ high-order resonant converter topologies with appropriately controlled multiple inverters and rectifiers in inductive and capacitive WPT systems to compensate for changes in coupling and achieve higher efficiency and reduced size, then validate these advantages through a series of experimental prototypes; and (iii) demonstrate feasibility of near-field focusing and enhanced safety through distributed WPT architectures by measuring the reduction in fringing fields in prototypes with different coupler geometries and configurations. This effort enables important innovations and fundamental advances. The step-superposition analysis technique developed here will enable accurate modeling and optimization of high-order resonant converters for WPT applications, as well as other power electronic and complex system applications. Having demonstrated high-order multi-inverter/rectifier resonant converters to provide efficiency benefits in grid-interfaced power electronics, the PI's research will introduce advanced variants that effectively compensate for variations in coupling in WPT systems, while operating at fixed frequency within ISM (i.e., industrial, scientific and medical) frequency bands. The research will also yield a better understanding of near-field phased-array field focusing through distributed couplers designed for field cancellation, and enable dramatic advances in power transfer densities and safety.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
Wireless power transfer (WPT) has the potential to reduce our energy footprint and improve our quality of life by enabling autonomous charging in applications ranging from electric vehicles (EVs) to biomedical implants. For example, in-motion WPT to EVs from the roadway can drastically reduce the need for onboard energy storage and reduce the cost of EVs. Likewise, effective WPT can enable artificial heart pumps without abdominal-wall-penetrating electric cords, avoiding discomfort and potential infections for the 6.2 million people in the U.S. suffering from heart failure. However, for WPT systems to be widely deployed, considerable improvements are needed in their efficiency, size, cost, and safety.

The research conducted under this project has developed and demonstrated dramatic improvements in large air-gap near-field wireless power transfer (WPT) systems through fundamental advancements in radio frequency power electronic technologies and novel approaches to WPT system design. Large air-gap WPT systems utilize inductively coupled coils or capacitively coupled conductive plates for energy transfer, and both approaches (inductive and capacitive) benefit from the developed advancements. A major contribution of this research has been the development of an improved design optimization approach for multistage matching networks that results in higher system efficiency. For example, by utilizing the developed approach, instead of the conventional approach, losses can be reduced by up to 65% in a two-stage L-section matching network. Matching networks are also used in other resonant power converter applications, such as power supplies for laptops, LED lighting, solar micro-inverters and electric vehicle chargers. Hence, this development has broad applications in the field of power electronics. This research has also led to the development of techniques for mitigating the effect of parasitic capacitances in capacitive WPT systems. Furthermore, this research has introduced novel approaches for reactive compensation in WPT systems, which enables effective power transfer to moving objects. The developed approaches to reactive compensation allows continuously variable reactance to be introduced in any resonant power conversion system without the need to change operating frequency or switch in or out reactive components. These approaches are valuable for both inductive and capacitive WPT systems. This research has also led to the development of multi-MHz kW-scale large air-gap capacitive WPT systems with unprecedented performance in terms of power transfer density and efficiency.

This project has also helped train multiple graduate and undergraduate students in the area of high frequency power electronics and wireless power transfer. The fundamental knowledge that has emerged from this research has also been incorporated into two power electronic courses. The results of this research have attracted support from industry for continued development of high-frequency WPT systems.

 


Last Modified: 07/21/2023
Modified by: Khurram K Afridi
